Hijacking top thread for this. According to the "assault weapons" ban in several northern states the criteria for being an assault weapon are:
Semi-automatic rifles able to accept detachable magazines and two or more of the following: -Folding or telescoping stock -Pistol grip -Bayonet mount -Flash suppressor, or threaded barrel designed to accommodate one -Grenade launcher mount
Let's dissect this for a second. I own an AR-15. I live in a state with more lenient gun laws. My AR-15 is semi-automatic and it came with a flash suppressor and a telescoping stock. My stock moves back and forth ~3 inches. The flash suppressor is screwed on the threaded barrel. This gun is illegal in northern states and qualifies as an "assault weapon". I can do 2 things. I can change my stock out to not move and I can have my flash suppressor pinned and welded to the gun. This gun would function the same. It shoots the same, it works the same, it shoots the same, but somehow this is considered an assault weapon. These liberal "common sense" laws have diverged into arbitrarily determining what is dangerous.
The second point is that there are firearms banned by make and model. This is the most insane thing to me. For example in New Jersey there's about 30 guns banned by MAKE. This is equivalent to banning Fords because of the name Ford. I assembled my AR-15, it's not a Colt. I can buy and assemble parts to make my AR-15 nearly identical to Colt's AR-15. Do people really think the company that manufactures the gun makes a difference?
#COMMON SENSE LAWS ARE NOT COMMON SENSE

No no of course the whole country gets to vote and obviously not everyone in CA and NY or the Midwest vote for the same person. However if we just went by the popular vote then the interests of those 12 states would be overshadowed by just 2 states. Not only that, but 2 coastal states would be the same as 12 rural states who probably have vastly different interests.
Listen I'm not trying to say the electoral college is perfect. Does it need to be tweaked? Probably. Does CA probably need more votes based on population? Probably. But if we got rid of the EC then smaller rural states would lose their sway in any election ever again.
Obviously I'm being hyperbolic, but there are 60 million people between those 2 states. The population of the Midwest is 65 million which is defined by the U.S. as 12 states. Seem fair?
